subject: Re: Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: ... saying ... Yes, I suppose after saying I thought Ted s proposal sounded reasonable, I have to agree with you. Another practical example that comes to mind
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> Alas, where syllable boundaries are to be drawn in English is a terribly
> vexed subject, so hard that most linguists either give up on the idea
> of doing so, counting syllables rather than delimiting them, or else
> simply admit that there are words where there are good reasons for
saying
> that one sound belongs to both syllables. Is it mon-ster, mons-ter,
> or monst-er? All are defensible choices, and dictionaries just record
> the more or less arbitrary rules used by printers in this matter, going
> for uniformity rather than impossible correctness.
>
> It may be that the number of ligatures is small enough that this never
> matters: I haven't tried to find out. (And what about Senior QS,
> where there are lots more ligatures?) But it's opening yet another
> can of worms.
>

Yes, I suppose after saying I thought Ted's proposal sounded
reasonable, I have to agree with you. Another practical example that
comes to mind is the word "merry," which I said in my last email
should not be formed with a ligature. But really why not use the Error
ligature, especially if you were writing it in senior QS? The Error
ligature I think would make the "er" combination easy to read, and I
am not even sure if the r in this word belongs to the first and second
syllable.

I think the one exception we should make is with Earth, which because
there is no QS letter for the vowel in this word, should only be used
for what is now Qs "ar." So the word "arrest" should not have the
Earth ligature in it. That is, unless we come up with another letter,
or if we decide to simply use Roar instead.

Paul
